Award.AwardTitle: RUI: High-Precision Atomic Structure Measurements and Tests of Fundamental Physics in Group IIIA Atoms
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research program, located at an undergraduate institution, involves table-top experiments with lasers and atoms to gain insights into the so-called "Standard Model of particle physics" that is typically studied by physicists at large particle accelerator facilities. In the present work, properties of the metal atoms thallium and indium are measured to very high accuracy. Results are then compared to state-of-the-art theoretical calculations of these same properties, as high-quality tests of the fundamental physics phenomena probed by these measurements rely critically on the combination of precise experimental results reinforced by accurate, independent atomic structure calculations. Students become involved in all aspects of the experimental work, designing and testing laser, optical, and signal processing systems, and carrying out data collection and data analysis procedures.

Over recent decades, highly-precise atomic physics experiments using lasers have contributed important insights into the physics of the Standard Model of particle physics. Such low-energy physics tests complement accelerator-based experimental work. The small size of these effects demands very high precision, extensive study of systematic errors, and careful experimental design. Also, the size of these manifestations of high-energy physics in atoms scale dramatically with Z, the atomic number, suggesting the use of very heavy (and therefore complicated) atomic systems. Yet in order for these measurements in heavy atoms to provide unambiguous tests of the Standard Model, equally precise atomic theory models of the atomic wavefunctions are required to distinguish the ordinary quantum mechanical behavior from the "exotic" particle physics phenomena being targeted. The PI and his students are continuing with an ongoing series of diode laser spectroscopy measurements of the atomic properties of Group IIIA atoms (thallium, indium) which can be compared to state-of-the-art atomic theory calculations. They study atoms both in heated vapor cells as well as a dense, collimated atomic beam apparatus. These atoms contain three valence electrons, challenging the approximation techniques required to accurately compute wavefunctions. This experiment-theory interplay has resulted in significantly improved accuracy in recent years, and therefore improved atomic-physics-based tests of fundamental particle physics processes in these heavy atomic systems. In the longer term, the group is planning to perform a new experiment to measure the Weak Interaction in an atomic beam of thallium atoms, using its parity-violating optical rotation signature, improving upon an experimental result by a group that included the PI some years ago.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research program, located at an undergraduate institution, focuses on very precise measurements of the properties of certain atoms using the technique of laser spectroscopy. As can be seen in the second attached picture showing the apparatus for our most recent experiment, the overall scale of the equipment is small, and involves lasers and a variety of tools to measure, stabilize, focus and direct the lasers to a large furnace where, here, heated lead atoms are the subject of study.  The lasers act as probes to reveal the underlying quantum-mechanical structure of the atoms.  Using our techniques we measure properties of these atoms that either have not been measured before, or we measure these properties with unprecedented precision.  Much of the work involves careful experimental design, processing of our signals to extract meaningful spectroscopic information, and substantial data analysis and modeling to understand the resulting detected signals.  

We work in close collaboration with a leading theoretical physics group who carry out calculations/predictions of the same atomic properties that we measure.  This interplay of theory and experiment has spurred on improvement both in theoretical modeling and in experimental techniques.

All of the work in our group at Williams College is carried out in collaboration with talented undergraduate students in this liberal-arts-college institution. The work provides research-training opportunities for undergraduate students at every stage of their education, many of whom grow to become research partners, co-author papers and conference presentations, and go on to attend highly-selective Ph.D. programs in physics and related disciplines.

This grant-funded work continues of a series of such relatively small-scale experiments using diode lasers and atoms which will help guide the refinement of atomic theory calculations in these complex many-electron atomic systems. As it turns out, these heavy atoms play an important role well beyond just 'atomic physics'.  Very precise measurements of their properties, using well-developed tools in carefully constructed and planned table-top experiments, can actually provide insight into the same kind of physics one normally associates with accelerators and high-energy particle physics.  After all, the same physics going on in particle accelerators is happening in ordinary matter -- the effects are just much smaller in ordinary atoms, and often masked by much larger effects that dominate the everyday behavior of these atoms.

In order for these experiments to make maximum impact along side these much larger-scale, much more expensive acclerator-based efforts, we must understand the complicated quantum mechanics (which now we would call 'ordinary' atomic physics), so that we can distinguish this from the more 'esoteric' physics.  Our work, in close collaboration with our theoretical colleagues, helps to improve this understanding.

Broader Impacts: 

In the course of this work, new experimental techniques associated with our high-precision spectroscopy have been developed which have broad applicability for the atomic physics community, and which we have shared through publications and presentations. 

At Williams College, these experiments have provided research opportunities for more than 60 undergraduates since the inception of the group?s NSF funding.  During the most recent NSF grant period, nine Williams students involved in experiments in this laboratory are now enrolled in, or are presently applying to, Ph.D. programs in physics or related fields.  Our group has received substantial recognition for its research and research-training efforts.  Two recent graduates of this research group were winners of the American Physical Society's  (APS) "LeRoy Apker Award" given annually to the top undergraduate research student in the country.  The PI was also selected in 2017 as the recipient of the APS Award to a faculty member for research at an undergraduate institution.  The attached primary image shows the PI at an annual professional meeting in Atomic Physics surrounded by former students all of whom have completed or are enrolled in PhD programs at Harvard (4), Yale, UChicago, UMaryland, and UColorado.

In this experimental laboratory, students take active, central roles in completing laboratory projects through which they develop specific expertise with optics and lasers, electronics and control systems, as well as sophisticated data analysis procedures while still appreciating the entirety of the relatively small-scale experimental work.  Of the 14 students supervised during the most recent grant period, six began their work as first or second-year undergraduates, seven were women, and two were from under-represented ethnic groups.  A continuing effort will be made to recruit students from a broad range of backgrounds, and to engage younger students at a crucial, early point in their undergraduate years, as they begin to make longer-term career choices. 

We are committed to contributing to the important mission of training the next generation of scientists through this NSF-funded work.
